column4: i am trying to restore some data off of a hard drive, and it is seemingly unformatted (i.e. partition table is corrupt). I was going to rip the data using dd, but it was going unusually slow. The drive is now not even being properly recognised. I am monitoring /var/log/messages and it's throwing some interesting things..
i desperately need the data from this drive, so if anyone can help me 'decode' the messages I would appreciate it. I can pastebin it
go go pastebin
where are you trying to retrieve data from?? a CD or HD?
it is a sata 2.5" HDD, in a usb enclosure
wish I could make heads or tails of what I'm looking at but it looks like a corrupt sector on the disk
but that's a guess
that is what I am thinking, however earlier it was not doing this and was just saying no partition type kinda thing
do you have the earlier output?
no unfortunately, it was similar to the one i posted except it didnt keep doing that illegal request... cycle.
Does this happen when attempting to mount the drive or when attempting to read?
as soon as i plug it in, it refuses to mount. It was reading earlier very very slowly with dd, but that kinda access is no more :(
Sounds like the drive died. All other USB storage devices are being read fine?
eya, that is a bummer... window refuses to recognise it too, but thats not a surprise...
I would say the drive's dead then
damn, its a mates and its ot soe really important stuff on it.. oh well, you win some you lose some
Was the drive sounding like a ticker tape earlier?
Rapid clicking noises during heavy operations?
No, i've had plenty of tickers in the past and this isn't one. I'd say the hardware sounds fine, spins fine etc... must be a sector issue...
In that case your guess is probably accurate
short of a low-level format, can sectors be repaired without removing the important data?
from what I know, Not really because most causes of bad sectors are physical damage of some sort. however data can be retrieved depending on how much of the data was located in said sectors
right then, well thanks for your assistance and your time... i'll go give him the bad news :(
